standard_metadata.standard_description: Solve unit rate problems including those involving unit pricing and constant speed.

question.content: At the market, $8$ batteries cost $\$10$.  **How much do $6$ batteries cost?**  $\$ $

hints.content: We’re trying to find the cost of $6$ batteries.  Batteries | Cost (dollars) :-: | :-: $\redE{8}$ | $\maroonE{10}$ $\downarrow \div 8$ | $\downarrow \div 8$ $1$ | $1.25$  If $\redE{8}$ batteries cost $\maroonE{\$10}$, then $1$ battery costs $\$1.25$.
Batteries | Cost (dollars) :-: | :-: $\redE{8}$ | $\maroonE{10}$ $1$ | $1.25$ $\downarrow \times 6$ | $\downarrow \times 6$ $\purpleD{6}$ | $\goldE{7.50}$
**So, $\purpleD{6}$ batteries cost $\goldE{\$7.50}$.**

question.content: At the market, $5$ light bulbs cost $\$9$.  **How much do $7$ light bulbs cost?**  $\$ $

hints.content: We’re trying to find the cost of $7$ light bulbs.  Light bulbs | Cost (dollars) :-: | :-: $\redE{5}$ | $\maroonE{9.00}$ $\downarrow \div 5$ | $\downarrow \div 5$ $1$ | $1.80$  If $\redE{5}$ light bulbs cost $\maroonE{\$9}$, then $1$ light bulb costs $\$1.80$.
Light bulbs | Cost (dollars) :-: | :-: $\redE{5}$ | $\maroonE{9.00}$ $1$ | $1.80$ $\downarrow \times 7$ | $\downarrow \times 7$ $\purpleD{7}$ | $\goldE{12.60}$
**So, $\purpleD{7}$ light bulbs cost $\goldE{\$12.60}$.**

question.content: A plane flew at a constant speed and traveled $762$ miles in $5$ hours.    **How many miles would the plane travel in $3$ hours at the same speed?**   miles

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of miles the plane could travel in $3$ hours.  Hours | Miles :-: | :-: $\redE{5}$ | $\maroonE{762}$ $\downarrow \div 5$ | $\downarrow \div 5$ $1$ | $152.4$  If in $\redE{5}$ hours, the plane can travel $\maroonE{762}$ miles, then in $1$ hour, the plane can travel $152.4$ miles.
Hours | Miles :-: | :-: $\redE{5}$ | $\maroonE{762}$ $1$ | $152.4$ $\downarrow \times 3$ | $\downarrow \times 3$ $\purpleD{3}$ | $\goldE{457.2}$
**So, in $\purpleD{3}$ hours, the plane can travel $\goldE{457.2}$ miles.**

question.content: At the market, $8$ apples cost $\$4$.  **How much do $9$ apples cost?**  $\$ $

hints.content: We’re trying to find the cost of $9$ apples.  Apples | Cost (dollars) :-: | :-: $\redE{8}$ | $\maroonE{4.00}$ $\downarrow \div 8$ | $\downarrow \div 8$ $1$ | $0.50$  If $\redE{8}$ apples cost $\maroonE{\$4}$, then $1$ apple costs $\$0.50$.
Apples | Cost (dollars) :-: | :-: $\redE{8}$ | $\maroonE{4.00}$ $1$ | $0.50$ $\downarrow \times 9$ | $\downarrow \times 9$ $\purpleD{9}$ | $\goldE{4.50}$
**So, $\purpleD{9}$ apples cost $\goldE{\$4.50}$.**

question.content: Amanda can jog $18$ miles in $5$ hours.    **At this rate,  how many miles can Amanda jog in $4$ hours?**   miles

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of miles Amanda can jog in $4$ hours.  Hours | Miles :-: | :-: $\redE{5}$ | $\maroonE{18}$ $\downarrow \div 5$ | $\downarrow \div 5$ $1$ | $3\dfrac{3}{5}$  If in $\redE{5}$ hours Amanda can jog $\maroonE{18}$ miles, then in $1$ hour she can jog $3\dfrac35$ miles.
Hours | Miles :-: | :-: $\redE{5}$ | $\maroonE{18}$ $1$ | $3\dfrac{3}{5}$ $\downarrow \times 4$ | $\downarrow \times 4$ $\purpleD{4}$ | $\goldE{14\dfrac{2}{5}}$
**So, in $\purpleD{4}$ hours, Amanda can jog $\goldE{14\dfrac25}$ miles.**

question.content: Henry can write $5$ pages of his novel in $3$ hours.    **At this rate, how many pages can Henry write in $8$ hours?**   pages

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of pages Henry can write in $8$ hours.  Hours | Pages :-: | :-: $\redE{3}$ | $\maroonE{5}$ $\downarrow \div 3$ | $\downarrow \div 3$ $1$ | $1\dfrac{2}{3}$  If in $\redE{3}$ hours Henry can write $\maroonE{5}$ pages, then in $1$ hour he can write $1\dfrac23$ pages.

Hours | Pages :-: | :-: $\redE{3}$ | $\maroonE{5}$ $1$ | $1\dfrac{2}{3}$ $\downarrow \times 8$ | $\downarrow \times 8$ $\purpleD{8}$ | $\goldE{13 \dfrac{1}{3}}$  A fractional number of pages makes sense, because it is possible to write part of a page.
**So, in $\purpleD{8}$ hours, Henry can write $\goldE{13\dfrac13}$ or $\goldE{\dfrac{40}{3}}$ pages.**

question.content: Tommy can exchange $8$ euros for $11$ dollars.    **At this rate, how many dollars can Tommy get with $12$ euros?**   dollars

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of dollars Tommy can get with $12$ euros.  Euros | Dollars :-: | :-: $\redE{8}$ | $\maroonE{11}$ $\downarrow \div 8$ | $\downarrow \div 8$ $1$ | $1\dfrac{3}{8}$  If Tommy can exchange $\redE{8}$ euros for $\maroonE{11}$ dollars, then he can exchange $1$ euro for $1\dfrac38$ dollars.
Euros | Dollars :-: | :-: $\redE{8}$ | $\maroonE{11}$ $1$ | $1\dfrac{3}{8}$ $\downarrow \times 12$ | $\downarrow \times 12$ $\purpleD{12}$ | $\goldE{16\dfrac{1}{2}}$
**So, with $\purpleD{12}$ euros, Tommy can exchange for $\goldE{16\dfrac12}$ or $\goldE{16.50}$ dollars.**

question.content: Heather is a cashier. She can ring up  $12$ customers in $9$ minutes.    **At this rate, how many minutes does it take her to ring up $4$ customers?**   minutes

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of minutes it takes Heather to ring up $4$ customers.    Customers | Minutes :-: | :-: $\redE{12}$ | $\maroonE{9}$ $\downarrow \div 12$ | $\downarrow \div 12$ $1$ | $\dfrac{3}{4}$  If Heather can ring up $\redE{12}$ customers in $\maroonE{9}$ minutes, then she can ring up $1$ customer in $\dfrac34$ of a minute.
Customers | Minutes :-: | :-: $\redE{12}$ | $\maroonE{9}$ $1$ | $\dfrac{3}{4}$ $\downarrow \times 4$ | $\downarrow \times 4$ $\purpleD{4}$ | $\goldE{3}$
**So, Heather can ring up $\purpleD{4}$ customers in $\goldE{3}$ minutes.**

question.content: Luke can paint $91$ portraits in $7$ weeks.  **How many portraits can Luke paint in $4$ weeks?**   portraits

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of portraits Luke can paint in $4$ weeks.  Weeks | Portraits :-: | :-: $\redE{7}$ | $\maroonE{91}$ $\downarrow \div 7$ | $\downarrow \div 7$ $1$ | $13$  If in $\redE{7}$ weeks, Luke can paint $\maroonE{91}$ portraits, then in $1$ week, he can paint $13$ portraits.
Weeks | Portraits :-: | :-: $\redE{7}$ | $\maroonE{91}$ $1$ | $13$ $\downarrow \times 4$ | $\downarrow \times 4$ $\purpleD{4}$ | $\goldE{52}$
**So, in $\purpleD{4}$ weeks, Luke can paint $\goldE{52}$ portraits.**

question.content: Charles can type $675$ words in $9$ minutes.    **How many words can Charles type in $13$ minutes?**   words

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of words Charles can type in $13$ minutes.  Minutes | Words :-: | :-: $\redE{9}$ | $\maroonE{675}$ $\downarrow \div 9$ | $\downarrow \div 9$ $1$ | $75$  If in $\redE{9}$ minutes, Charles can type $\maroonE{675}$ words, then in $1$ minute, he can type $75$ words.
Minutes | Words :-: | :-: $\redE{9}$ | $\maroonE{675}$ $1$ | $75$ $\downarrow \times 13$ | $\downarrow \times 13$ $\purpleD{13}$ | $\goldE{975}$
**So, in $\purpleD{13}$ minutes, Charles can type $\goldE{975}$ words.**

question.content: Bill can hit a bucket of $323$ golf balls in $17$ hours.  **How many golf balls can Bill hit in $23$ hours?**   golf balls

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of golf balls Bill can hit in $23$ hours.  Hours | Golf balls :-: | :-: $\redE{17}$ | $\maroonE{323}$ $\downarrow \div 17$ | $\downarrow \div 17$ $1$ | $19$  If in $\redE{17}$ hours, Bill can hit $\maroonE{323}$ golf balls, then in $1$ hour, he can hit $19$ golf balls.
Hours | Golf balls :-: | :-: $\redE{17}$ | $\maroonE{323}$ $1$ | $19$ $\downarrow \times 23$ | $\downarrow \times 23$ $\purpleD{23}$ | $\goldE{437}$
**So, in $\purpleD{23}$ hours, Bill can hit $\goldE{437}$ golf balls.**

question.content: Frances can complete $91$ oil changes in $7$ days.  **How many oil changes can Frances complete in $11$ days?**   oil changes

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of oil changes Frances can complete in $11$ days.  Days | Oil changes :-: | :-: $\redE{7}$ | $\maroonE{91}$ $\downarrow \div 7$ | $\downarrow \div 7$ $1$ | $13$  If in $\redE{7}$ days, Frances can complete $\maroonE{91}$ oil changes, then in $1$ day, she can complete $13$ oil changes.
Days | Oil changes :-: | :-: $\redE{7}$ | $\maroonE{91}$ $1$ | $13$ $\downarrow \times 11$ | $\downarrow \times 11$ $\purpleD{11}$ | $\goldE{143}$
**So, in $\purpleD{11}$ days, Frances can complete $\goldE{143}$ oil changes.**

question.content: Robin can clean $72$ rooms in $6$ days.  **How many rooms can Robin clean in $9$ days?**   rooms

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of rooms Robin can clean in $9$ days.  Days | Rooms :-: | :-: $\redE{6}$ | $\maroonE{72}$ $\downarrow \div 6$ | $\downarrow \div 6$ $1$ | $12$  If in $\redE{6}$ days, Robin can clean $\maroonE{72}$ rooms, then in $1$ day, she can clean $12$ rooms.
Days | Rooms :-: | :-: $\redE{6}$ | $\maroonE{72}$ $1$ | $12$ $\downarrow \times 9$ | $\downarrow \times 9$ $\purpleD{9}$ | $\goldE{108}$
**So, in $\purpleD{9}$ days, Robin can clean $\goldE{108}$ rooms.**

question.content: Brenda can deliver $644$ newspapers in $7$ hours.  **How many newspapers can Brenda deliver in $9$ hours?**   newspapers

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of newspapers Brenda can deliver in $9$ hours.  Hours | Newspapers :-: | :-: $\redE{7}$ | $\maroonE{644}$ $\downarrow \div 7$ | $\downarrow \div 7$ $1$ | $92$  If in $\redE{7}$ hours, Brenda can deliver $\maroonE{644}$ newspapers, then in $1$ hour, she can deliver $92$ newspapers.
Hours | Newspapers :-: | :-: $\redE{7}$ | $\maroonE{644}$ $1$ | $92$ $\downarrow \times 9$ | $\downarrow \times 9$ $\purpleD{9}$ | $\goldE{828}$
**So, in $\purpleD{9}$ hours, Brenda can deliver $\goldE{828}$ newspapers.**

question.content: Lynnette can wash $95$ cars in $5$ days.  **How many cars can Lynnette wash in $11$ days?**   cars

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of cars Lynnette can wash in $11$ days.  Days | Cars :-: | :-: $\redE{5}$ | $\maroonE{95}$ $\downarrow \div 5$ | $\downarrow \div 5$ $1$ | $19$  If in $\redE{5}$ days, Lynnette can wash $\maroonE{95}$ cars, then in $1$ day, she can wash $19$ cars.
Days | Cars :-: | :-: $\redE{5}$ | $\maroonE{95}$ $1$ | $19$ $\downarrow \times 11$ | $\downarrow \times 11$ $\purpleD{11}$ | $\goldE{209}$
**So, in $\purpleD{11}$ days, Lynnette can wash $\goldE{209}$ cars.**

question.content: Alicia drove at a constant speed and traveled $183$ miles in $3$ hours.    **How many miles would Alicia travel in $11$ hours at the same speed?**   miles

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of miles Alicia would travel in $11$ hours.  Hours | Miles :-: | :-: $\redE{3}$ | $\maroonE{183}$ $\downarrow \div 3$ | $\downarrow \div 3$ $1$ | $61$  If in $\redE{3}$ hours, Alicia traveled $\maroonE{183}$ miles, then in $1$ hour, she would travel $61$ miles.
Hours | Miles :-: | :-: $\redE{3}$ | $\maroonE{183}$ $1$ | $61$ $\downarrow \times 11$ | $\downarrow \times 11$ $\purpleD{11}$ | $\goldE{671}$
**So, in $\purpleD{11}$ hours, Alicia would travel $\goldE{671}$ miles.**

question.content: Ken can walk $40$ dogs in $8$ hours.  **How many dogs can Ken walk in $12$ hours?**   dogs

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of dogs Ken can walk in $12$ hours.  Hours | Dogs :-: | :-: $\redE{8}$ | $\maroonE{40}$ $\downarrow \div 8$ | $\downarrow \div 8$ $1$ | $5$  If in $\redE{8}$ hours, Ken can walk $\maroonE{40}$ dogs, then in $1$ hour, he can walk $5$ dogs.
Hours | Dogs :-: | :-: $\redE{8}$ | $\maroonE{40}$ $1$ | $5$ $\downarrow \times 12$ | $\downarrow \times 12$ $\purpleD{12}$ | $\goldE{60}$
**So, in $\purpleD{12}$ hours, Ken can walk $\goldE{60}$ dogs.**

question.content: Mark can make $42$ birthday cakes in $7$ days.  **How many birthday cakes can Mark make in $5$ days?**   birthday cakes

hints.content: We’re trying to find the number of cakes Mark can make in $5$ days.  Days | Cakes :-: | :-: $\redE{7}$ | $\maroonE{42}$ $\downarrow \div 7$ | $\downarrow \div 7$ $1$ | $6$  If in $\redE{7}$ days, Mark can make $\maroonE{42}$ cakes, then in $1$ day, he can make $6$ cakes.
Days | Cakes :-: | :-: $\redE{7}$ | $\maroonE{42}$ $1$ | $6$ $\downarrow \times 5$ | $\downarrow \times 5$ $\purpleD{5}$ | $\goldE{30}$
**So, in $\purpleD{5}$ days, Mark can make $\goldE{30}$ cakes.**
